captions.text:
Good morning, John. Today we're going to be
doing something a little bit different. I'm

gonna be holding a debate here in my house
around the topic of net neutrality, featuring

me, an internet user and me, representing
a cable company, on opposite sides of the
table, literally.

Internet User Hank: First things first, for
the viewers at home I think we should just
define what net neutrality is.

Cable Company Hank: Sounds like a fine place
to begin.

IUH: So net neutrality is the idea that internet
service providers should provide access to

all of the internet at the same speed: no
matter what content it is, no one gets any
preference.

CCH: Fair definition; the question is: is
that a good idea? Like why should I, an internet

service provider, have to provide Game of
Thrones via BitTorrent at the same speed as
I provide it through HBO Go?

IUH: I don't know, cause you're not a law
enforcement agency and that's not your job,

but like, you shouldn't be determining how
your users use your service. It's the internet;

you just provide access to it and, but like,
my concern is that if you do it to BitTorrent

that you'll do it to, like, a legitimate competitor
to your business, like Netflix for example.
CCH: No one is talking about doing that.

IUH: I mean, you say that, but yeah they are.
Like Comcast literally slowed down Netflix's

internet connection and forced them to pay
to get faster access to their customers; like
it happened already.

CCH: Netflix is responsible for over 30% of
the bandwidth use of the US. Why should all

of our customers, regardless of whether they
use Netflix, be required to pay for the massive

infrastructure upgrades necessary to provide
that service. Of course Netflix should pay.

But, we're not talking about slowing down
Netflix to make them pay. We're just saying

we're going to speed Netflix up if they do
pay.

IUH: I mean if you sped Netflix up without
adding any new bandwidth, wouldn't you definitionally

slow someone else down in order to speed Netflix
up? You are, right now, for the first time

in American history, making the internet a
non-level playing field. You talk high and

mighty about economic efficiency, but what
creates great economies is not profit; it's

competition, which is what you're trying to
destroy.

CCH: I mean, the internet's a mature industry
now; we can't keep running around like it's

1998 hippie-fun-feel-good times. It's time
to buckle down and turn this thing into a

real economic engine. We want to charge customers
for access to content and charge content companies

for access to the customers. We get paid twice,
it's great for us!

IUH: The internet is not your business model.
The internet is a massive, technological,

and economic, and cultural force for good
that everyone should have equal access to,

and your place as a middle-man does not bequeath
you magical powers to extract value at every

turn! You have no right to decide what information
goes at what speed through your pipes.

CCH: I mean, don't we though? We're already
doing it with Netflix; we kind of already

set the precedent. Let's face it, this is
a complicated legal thing, and with the potential

upside for us, we can afford a lot of lawyers
and lobbyists. No offense, but I don't think
you can play on our level.

IUH: I guess we'll see. John, I'll see you
on Tuesday.

Hi. I'm a little bit worried about this. I
want the internet to remain open and neutral

in America... for selfish and also altruistic
reasons. You can help. And please do; the

FCC is currently asking for comments. Please
go to comment at the FCC's website, there's

a link in the description. Tell them to classify
broadband internet as a common carrier service,

which will prevent telecoms from making the
internet a closed, non-neutral place. If you

want to help in more long-term ways, in the
description there are a few organizations

that are working on these issues, actually
hiring lawyers and lobbyists to compete with

the telecoms. You can give them money; you
can give them your time; you can give them

your action, and you can call your congress
people. I love the internet a lot and I bet

that you do too, and I am worried what's gonna
happen if we let the middlemen decide what

the internet is like. Frankly, I don't trust
'em.

title: Hank vs. Hank: The Net Neutrality Debate in 3 Minutes

comments.author: Effect

comments.text:
+Effect , come on man!  If you going to talk about this, try reading the 
links you post, and use your brain a bit!

The VPN test still proves nothing because it causes the traffic to use 
Different Pipes.  This isn't proof of "intentional throttling" in the 
least.  It's proof of "if you route traffic away from the congestion, it 
will probably flow better".

So we're back to this: the pipes originally agreed to were at capacity.  If 
someone wants more pipes, they pay for them to be implemented.  Just as if 
you want faster internet at home, you pay for the faster package.  There is 
nothing wrong with this.  Keeping extra connection points open allows for 
quicker expansion when needed.  Could Comcast charitably offer a better 
interconnect?  sure, and mcdonalds could feed all the hungry.  But maybe 
they're reserving those ports for another interconnect thats in the works.  
The thing is WE DON'T KNOW.  And there is ZERO EVIDENCE of malevolence.

Even in the mattvukas link you posted, he admits his test was garbage.

The Extremetech one at least tries to be honest when it says, "using a VPN, 
[Verizon's] own FiOS customer is routing traffic through ports and 
connections that aren’t reserved for Netflix. Since those services have 
much more available bandwidth, the VPN’s performance speeds up." -- but 
then they go off rails when they interject their opinion on why they don't 
think that could actually be the reason.

another quote from your articles: "No one has actually shown beyond a 
shadow of a doubt that ISPs directly throttle Netflix traffic."

and another: "Netflix performance does vary by ISP, but we can't rule out 
the possibility that Netflix's own practices are causing bad outcomes for 
consumers. It's also possible that no one is doing anything particularly 
nefarious."

comments.text:
+Jack Williams +Effect 

This is where you need to use your brain a little.  Suspend your emotional 
prejudice, and exercise your Reason.  And take note of some Facts:

- End users saw a decrease in speed because Netflix's 3rd party pipe to 
Comcast was at capacity.
- Netflix had the choice of keeping the less-than-desirable 3rd party pipe, 
or upgrading to a fatter, direct pipe to Comcast. 
- Netflix chose to ensure better customer experience and they opted to 
upgrade their pipe.
- Once Netflix upgraded their pipe, the speeds to Comcast customers 
increased to be better than ever.
- In the end, the customer won, and all this without the need for the heavy 
hand of govt.

Now consider these points:
- If Comcast was throttling, then why did the fix have nothing to do with 
lifting speed caps or treating traffic differently?
- Your 40 Mbps connection to comcast is not a direct connection to 
Netflix.  This is like saying my computer has a 1Gb connection to my 
router, so i should have that speed to the internet.  It doesn't work like 
that.  The bottleneck is the weakest link in the end-to-end connection.  So 
the first bottleneck is your 40Mbps connection.  Then if you're trying to 
access a personal server hosted on a 1Mbps DSL connection, your original 
1Gb connection is now only working at 1Mbps.  So your 40 Mbps connection 
was bottlenecked by Netflix's 3rd party pipe.

Following so far?  Let me know if you need anything else cleared up.

I think a regulation for non-throttled, dumb pipe broadband should be set, 
they can still charge what they want for different levels of service.

The fact stands that telecommunications is one of the single greatest 
promoters to human progress. To slow it down causes progress to slow down.

Imagine if it takes 1m people 1ms longer on every mb downloaded, 
downloading an average of 100mb a day. That's 2.78h lost per day, and 42 
days lost per year. That's 356 days lost for the city of New York. Almost 
an entire year of labor lost for an entire city. These are extremely low 
balled estimates, and the actual impact is much greater.

Regulating net neutrality only stands to benefit economy, and the human

comments.text:
+Allballz When a government granted monopoly exists, who else besides the 
government can fix it?  Your logic is badly broken.  No matter what the 
"fix" is it requires some change of regulation at the government level.  
The current laws give telecoms monopolies to bring internet the "last mile" 
to your home.  If we're keeping those laws then we need to ensure that the 
telecoms honor net neutrality.

Or we could de-regulate them and eliminate the monopoly.  However there are 
very practical reasons why this won't happen.  It's not practical for a 
dozen different phone and cable companies to dig trenches along your street 
and dig up your driveways to install new cabling so they can compete for 
your business.

As a libertarian I must still understand that some amount of government 
regulation is needed.  Common access to things like phone, cable, and 
roadways is good for everyone and it doesn't make sense for dozens of 
companies to build competing roads or install competing electric, phone, 
and cable lines because then there'd be no land left to live on, rural 
areas would be criss-crossed with nothing but wires and roads.

So knowing that it's practically impossible to completely de-regulate the 
last mile of internet service we need to decide what the compromise looks 
like.  Yes it'd be nice if the solution was simply more competition, but if 
that's not possible we need to make sure that when our tax money is used to 
grant a company a monopoly to provide us a service (At a cost to us) that 
at least we don't let them abuse that monopoly.  Therefore where a monopoly 
exists net neutrality regulation should also exist.

It should also be made clear that there is no new regulation here.  We're 
talking about treating internet service providers as "common carriers" 
under laws that have existed since 1934 for all "common carriers".

Also keep in mind that these monopolies were granted to companies like AT&T 
and Verizon after AT&T and Verizon made legal *commitments* to use there 
monopolies and tax money we granted them to actually build out broadband 
networks which they never followed through on.  They built very limited 
networks in very limited areas and they continue to point to that and 
exclaim about how they've fulfilled their commitments.  However the reality 
is that if you're shopping for a home, if you want to live anywhere besides 
an apartment or deep in a newly developed subdivision your broadband 
choices are terrible at best.  I've been house shopping for 9 months around 
Austin, TX and I struggle to find properties with better than 10 Mbps 
speeds.  Almost half of the properties that I look at have no internet at 
all.  (I'd have to do wireless).

Some of these properties are within the city limits!  I currently live in a 
home outside the city limits with 1Gbps of broadband because I happen to 
live in one of the tiny slivers of Austin where AT&T offers Gigapower. (And 
even that only exists because of competition from Google fiber).

The bottom line is the current system is badly broken and needs to be 
revamped.  Either we de-regulate alltogether (Which is impractical) or we 
make sure that the regulation prohibits ISPs from abusing their monopolies 
over us.  I honestly don't understand the push-back over this.

This philosophy, while nice in theory, would not work it practice. The 
reasons for this are twofold.
Primarily, you can't just pick whatever ISP you want. It's not like, say, 
cell phone companies, where you can get pretty much any cell phone carrier 
anywhere in the US. You can only chose an ISP that services and had 
infrastructure in your area. Often, an ISP will have a monopoly over a 
given area, and you don't have a choice. You have to use that ISP if you 
want Internet. In a monopoly, capitalism doesn't work.
Secondly, it is in the best interest of the ISPs to work together. That's 
one of the reasons why they often have so many monopolies. It is extremely 
unlikely that an ISP wouldn't offer multiple tiered services if they had 
the choice, because it is in the best interest of all the ISPs if they all 
just agree to offer the same tiered services.

comments.text:
+Brendan Downey
You need to do some research on these government-created monopolies. From 
the Wikipedia page on the East India Company:

"...on 31 December 1600, the Queen granted a Royal Charter to "George, Earl 
of Cumberland, and 215 Knights, Aldermen, and Burgesses" under the name, 
Governor and Company of Merchants of London trading with the East 
Indies.[9] For a period of fifteen years the charter awarded the newly 
formed company a monopoly on trade with all countries east of the Cape of 
Good Hope and west of the Straits of Magellan.... The prosperity that the 
officers of the company enjoyed allowed them to return to Britain and 
establish sprawling estates and businesses, and to obtain political power. 
The company developed a lobby in the English parliament. Under pressure 
from ambitious tradesmen and former associates of the company (pejoratively 
termed Interlopers by the company), who wanted to establish private trading 
firms in India, a deregulating act was passed in 1694.[17]
This allowed any English firm to trade with India, unless specifically 
prohibited by act of parliament, thereby annulling the charter that had 
been in force for almost 100 years. By an act that was passed in 1698, a 
new "parallel" East India Company (officially titled the English Company 
Trading to the East Indies) was floated under a state-backed indemnity of 
£2 million. The powerful stockholders of the old company quickly subscribed 
a sum of £315,000 in the new concern, and dominated the new body. The two 
companies wrestled with each other for some time, both in England and in 
India, for a dominant share of the trade.[17]
It quickly became evident that, in practice, the original company faced 
scarcely any measurable competition."

Exclusive charter to trade with half the world? Sounds like mercantilism to 
me (an early form of fascism). It was hardly laissez-faire. What do you 
think was one of the main points of friction between the crown and the 
American colonies? The flouting by American smugglers of the exclusive 
shipping privileges awarded by the crown.

Try running a small business. It is an eye-opener. See how much of your 
time is spent in pointless dancing with bureaucrats.

About restaurant health codes, have you never got sick from eating out?

The problem a lot of people have with the idea of liberty is that they take 
the current situation and envision removing some form of government 
regulation, with no other changes. Then they say "that can't work". But 
that is not realistic. People change their behavior to conform to the new 
reality. Restaurant owners form voluntary associations to police their own 
behaviors - for their own self interest, because they don't want their 
customers getting sick. Restaurant customers look for that certification 
when they go out, or just stick with restaurants they know.

Perfection is not possible, with regulation or without it. But one thing I 
am sure of is that liberty is the best thing that ever happened to the 
human race. Not all people seem to want it, and that is OK with me; but I 
don't like being dragooned into others' socialist or fascist utopias.

bandwidth during peak hours.... are you really behaving as though they do 
not have a higher duty to pay a premium than other companies?

Tell me... do you think it's fair that industrial end-users pay more for 
power during peak hours? I bet you think that's fair...

Do you think it's fair that 18-wheelers pay a higher toll than you do to 
move their goods across toll roads? I bet you do think that's fair.

Do you think it's fair that golf courses and wealthy people who like to 
water their 20-acre yard every day of the summer pay more for a gallon of 
water than you do? I bet you think that's fair too...

So tell me... if you think all those things are fair... which I'm sure you 
do... why do you throw that logic out the window when it applies to the 
internet? I think you're being a bit naive and childish about what the 
internet actually is, and how much money and work goes into updating and 
maintaining it. Your on the side right now that says you have the same 
exact duty to pay for a toll road as an 18-wheeler. You have the same duty 
to pay for a gallon of water as a golf course who uses millions of gallons 
a month... that's the crap you're supporting right now.

Just because you like Google, and don't know shit about Comcast or Level3 
doesn't mean that Net Neutrality is a good thing. Net Neutrality is simply 
maintaining Google's profit margins wrapped up in the bullshit of 
"protecting the little guy".

Always be skeptical when a multi-billion dollar company says they're 
fighting for the little guy. Usually that's code word for: "We're fighting 
for our own interests.. and the consumer will end up paying more anyways, 
we just don't want to pay"

Please... read up more on this...
